story:
Give voice to SURVIVOR ART. 

Empower inner-city girls who live beyond the stigmas of exploitation.

The 2nd Annual EMPOWER ME ART EXHIBIT & FUNDRAISER is to honoring and supporting the Art forms of girls in the inner city. On July 3rd 2016, artwork created by survivors-children-girls in the greater Bay Area will be featured in a local art gallery and sold to the community to support the young artist who created them!

Brilliant expressions and reflections of our daughters will be on display as an involved and informed discussion opener on sex-trafficking. Empowering the community start talking about the issue of sex-trafficking

By successfully fundraising $5,013. The 2nd Annual Empower Me Art Exhibit & Fundraiser will empower 7 female artists from the Bay Area who live beyond the stigmas of exploitation whom are mere children in a sex-trafficking arena, while simultaneously arming a community of men, women and children with the awareness, compassion and wear with all to stand firm in a message of . . . .

"Empowered Women, give birth to Empowered Communities."

All proceeds directly benefit the victims of sex trafficking. These children are our my only concern.

How it all got started?

After working in human services for more than 10 years Kristy has evolved herself on every level. Armed with new skills and a better perspective more than ever, organized and energized.

"Initiating a renewed cultural identity and unifying cultural experiences for encouragement through Art, but more importantly, for Healing." Kristy Lively continues to instill a program of action for inner-city girls~ to give voice to daughters of today who strive to live beyond the stigmas of exploitation and sex-trafficking.

In an effort to support and honor the girls she worked with In May 2015 Kristy gave birth to the 1st Annual EMPWR ME ART EXHIBIT & FUNDRAISER in Oakland, California.

As a supporter, we have many goodies to offer. . .

This year we have some exciting gifts for our supporters!

Ranging from personally signed reproductions of the girls art to our Gold & Platinum supporters, including a ferry ride to Sausalito,  lunch with a chance to share your ideas on how, we as a community can combat the exploitation and sex trafficking of our daughters in the Bay Area.

With the support of backers, and the tenacity to keep this tradition, this homage to inner-city girls ongoing. I know this event will be a huge success AGAIN and AGAin in cities all across the nation!


Why your support can make this event a success!

In order to improve upon our success at last years EMPWR ME ART Exhibit & Fundraiser event and to bring an even stronger message of solidarity with the girls whose art will be featured at the 2nd Annual Empower Me Art Exhibit & Fundraiser. We are seeking to raise $5,013 in funds.

25% of donations = $1250 will be allocated to securing catering services. We would like to provide refreshments, drinks, coffee, desserts and cutlery for at least 150 guest. Wine and other accouterments will be donated by local business and artisans who are committed to this event. We anticipate reaching our venues capacity, which is more than 300.

20% of donations = $1000 will be allocated to buy the necessary art materials (i.e. acrylic paint sets, brushes, labels, clay molds, various canvas sizes, drawing paper, other multi-media supplies including the cost of framing each piece.

17% of donations = $850 est. will be allocated to the cost of securing the venue. The 2nd Annual EMPWR Me Art Exhibit & Fundraiser is proposed to be hosted at Oakland's IMPACT HUB OAKLAND which is a member based co-working space and event venue for entrepreneurs creating positive space. The childrens Artwork will be installed and featured in the Omi Gallery space, which is on the ground floor facing one of Oakland's highly foot-trafficked streets: 2323 Broadway Street, Oakland, CA 94612.

16.9% of donations = $845 which breaks down to ($169.00 per artist) will be allocated to gifting each artist with their own FAMILYTREEDNA Ancestry kit ---"designed for a single person's use."To be presented to each artist at the event. To encourage, to cultivate the importance of learning knowledge of self -as an inspiring artist, to gain insight into their ancestry, but most importantly a stronger sense of belonging- the most affirming feeling they need as girls from the community

14% of donations = $500 will be allocated to public relation and marketing collateral to promote the event. Postcards, posters and printing other various marketing materials will be included in this expense.

 8% of donations = $422.50 will be allocated to transporting the artist to and from the event's venue. It's an important element of the project, ensuring the artists arrive safely without having to arrange transportation for themselves and their families.

How your support makes an Impact

The average age of entry into sex exploitation or "the life" is 9 years old. From cities like Oakland, which are major hubs for sex-trafficking. By supporting this event we are making a difference twofolds on our communities sobriety about this issue and far reaching art forms that captures our daughters-children-survivors divine brilliance and ability to overcome, the worst adversity!

At our 1st Annual Empower Me Art Exhibit & Fundraiser, we received overwhelming praises by the community's and the girls. Including, firm commitments by community members, and Owner Joyce Gordon, of the Joyce Gordon Gallery to assist me in any future events that would support this community of CSEC "girls". For me, this was a testament to how powerful this event moved and informed the community.

Created to feature the Artwork of girls in our inner cities who strive to live beyond the stigmas of exploitation & sex trafficking.

What we learned from our last event!

Last year, at the 1st Annual Empower Me Art Exhibit & Fundraiser....we encountered a handful of obstacles....from securing the venue to opening the venue on time to the public the day of the event.

During the planning and implementation of the 1st Annual EMPWR ME ART EXHIBIT & FUNDRAISER -By not having an adequate budget to pay for a caterer, or even better marketing collateral, the ability to reach more community members and cater to the girls came at a minimum. I was the sole person working out the details of this most important event, from marketing to taking each young lady shopping for the day of the event. Proudly, I arrived at 5 am the day of the event -to iron the girls clothes. Made and prepared all the food for at least 75 guest and ensured everything was perfect for our 2pm opening.

I spent a total of less than half the proposed budget- to struggle to pull together last year’s event. I am confident with a budget we can genuinely put on an even better event, in which the community can be empowered to learn from the resilience of our daughters and ensure their artwork be recognized and appreciated by the greater Bay Area.

Give voice to SURVIVOR ART. Empower inner-city girls who live beyond the stigmas of exploitation. 

No amount is too small.

Right now you might not be able to donate!

That's okay too . . join the community and spread the word about the 2nd Annual Empower fMe Art Exhibit & Fundraiser via #2016EmpowerMeExihibit Facebook, Twitter, email, or messages in bottles at the beach --your support and commitment to reducing the age of entry of girls into "the life" and exploitation of our daughters- starts with just a conversation!

And that's all there is to it. Thank you so much!

story:
The Bass Station represents the journey toward spiritual enlightenment and rising to a higher consciousness. My art is guided by “beauty in simplicity” and inspired by music. As an experienced craftsman and scenic artist, I’ve conceptualized the Bass Station as the union of large installation art and music.

I view my installations as inspirational pieces that challenge people to dream bigger and evolve their consciousness to a state of being open to readily accept love and unity and to reject societally-imposed standards. I rely on the natural human desire for spirituality and exploring the unknown to guide my vision and shape my ideas to construct interactive art that encourages oneness. I find beauty in simplicity and straight lines to invoke a sense of uneasiness and to challenge what one believes to be safe. I incorporate steel in my designs for the clean aesthetic it provides – a blank space, if you will, to be filled with emotions, unrest, and desire.

The Bass Station was born from the depths of internal exploration and the subliminal arousal of music. It delivers its passengers to a journey of the unknown and asks if we are alone in this world or only a small part of what is yet to be discovered.

--Tony Slife

We’ve designed the installation to be simple to set up and tear down. The station deconstructs into 18 pieces, which connect to each other with steel sleeves and flanges. The completed piece weighs over 1,800 pounds and is structurally sound. Inside the station is a raised platform that serves as a DJ booth; the DJ looks out from the open top of the station. Rockville speakers, water effect lights, laser light projectors and LED tape lights mounted to the station frame will bring music and love to everyone. 

We hope to travel to burns and festivals with the Bass Station very soon.

story:
Short Summary

Hi! My name is Malgorzata Tyczynska but friends call me Pea. I'm a visual artist. I live in Northwood, on the outskirts of London, UK.

I am organising an exhibition to better promote my art and share my message with the world. The exhibition's theme is Botanical Dimensions and the presented artworks are going to revolve around the theme of plant life in surreal/psychedelic setting. The exhibition is going to happen from 16.04.2016 to 22.04.2016 in The Hive Dalston - an alternative cultural centre in London. Featured artworks shall include originals of my published works and a few premieres ;).

To encourage you and show my gratitude I have prepared a selection of prizes: quality signed prints of my works, t-shirts and vests with my art and art commissions.


Featured Artworks

Below please find some of the artworks that will be displayed during the exhibition. Those are also the artworks to choose from for your prints and wallpapers (see: perks).

Acorn is an Oak:



Poppy Fairy: 


Bees and flowers:


Entheogenic Experience:


Limefly:


Where the Flowers Meet:


Leafentine:



Giraff-a-chill:



Tell me your secrets, leaves:



What I need the funding for and prizes

I need the money to fund the following

  • Space rental
  • Prints and frames for the exhibition
  • Promotion (posters, leaflets etc.)
  • Transport
  • Preparation and sending of the prizes
Prizes are as follows:
  • GBP 5 - a digital thank you postcard and a piece of cake during the exhibition :)
  • GBP 10 - a digital thank you postcard, a piece of cake during the exhibition and you can have one of my featured artworks as a wallpaper*:
    *Landscape orientation pictures will work best as desktop wallpapers while portrait orientation pictures will do better as phone wallpapers.
  • GBP 15 - a digital thank you postcard, a piece of cake during the exhibition and an A5-size (14,8 x 21 cm) mounted and signed, high quality Giclée print of one of my featured artworks.
  • GBP 20 - a digital thank you postcard, a piece of cake during the exhibition and a B5-size (17,6 x 25 cm) mounted signed, high quality Giclée print of one of my featured artworks.
  • GBP 25 - a digital thank you postcard, a piece of cake during the exhibition and an A4-size (21 x 30 cm) mounted signed, high quality Giclée print of either Poppy Fairy or Acorn is an Oak (see featured artworks)


  • GBP 25 - a digital thank you postcard, a piece of cake during the exhibition and a t-shirt or a vest with one of the featured artworks or one of the following designs:

    Poisces:


    Flowersticks:

    Dark stag:

    Diabolos:

    I Love Circus:

    Light Stag:

    All designs are sublimated onto the fabric. That means they will neither fade nor wash off. Those prints are forever!
    Here are some sample garments:

       




  • GBP 25 - a digital thank you postcard, a piece of cake during the exhibition and I will draw your chosen person as an anime character
  • GBP 50 - a digital thank you postcard, a piece of cake during the exhibition and a botanical portrait commission - I will draw a portrait of your chosen person with your chosen plant weaved into it.
  • GBP 100 -  Thank you, thank you, thank you! A digital thank you postcard, a piece of cake during the exhibition and I will create an illustration or design of your choice.
  • GBP 250  - You are my angel! A digital thank you postcard, a piece of cake during the exhibition and I will draw a comic for you (either your idea or I can come up with one that will have you in it :)). The comic can be up to 10 pages long if black and white and up to 4 pages in full-colour.

The Impact

In my drawings and illustrations I try to capture the beauty of nature and of imagination. This exhibition will help me share my message with the world and hopefully it will inspire people to slow down and look at the beauty around them, to relax and let their minds wonder.

This exhibition will also make me extremely happy. It will help me to make one of my dreams come true and facilitate my development as a creator.

Risks & Challenges

The main risk is that not enough people will learn about this exhibition and thus that I won't have many visitors.

A big challenge for me will be also to organise everything as it is my first exhibition after all.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are broke but would love to help me do not worry, there are still ways you can help:

  • Share this campaign with your friends and with strangers, share it on social media, via e-mail, via pigeon, share it everywhere and with everyone, please! ;)

  • Come and help me set up on 16.04.2016 or come and help me wrap it all up on 22.04.2016.

Thanks a lot for reading through and for any help you can offer <3.

Do you have any questions? Please ask away - I'm here to help :).

It will help me to make one of my dreams come true and facilitate my development as a creator.

A big challenge for me will be also to organise everything as it is my first exhibition after all.
    Other Ways You Can Help If you are broke but would love to help me do not worry, there are still ways you can help:

Share this campaign with your friends and with strangers, share it on social media, via e-mail, via pigeon, share it everywhere and with everyone, please! ;)

Come and help me set up on 16.04.2016 or come and help me wrap it all up on 22.04.2016.

   Thanks a lot for reading through and for any help you can offer <3.Do you have any questions? Please ask away - I'm here to help :).

story:
Ready Made Before


The shopping bag of Rebis will be closed in a transparent box sealed.

  • If you do not open is an art object.
  • The Ready Made Before is made in a limited edition of 500 numbered pieces.
  • It will have a QR CODE that allow you to verify the authenticity and seeing the image of the object on the web.
  • If you open is a common shopping bag.


What We Need & What You Get

I need € 5000 per:

  • Create the online site where view the Ready Made Before and its certification.
  • Produce 500 boxes transparent PVC.
  • To produce the first 50 pieces to start production.
  • Activities to communication as a free book in PDF on the Ready Made Before that contains even a thank you to patrons
  • To pay communication and advertising.

I offer:

  • 50 Ready Made Before € 80 instead of € 89.90 each, which will be the official price.
  • 50 catalogs in paper Mostra Prima di Rebis 10 € each one
  • To 100 patrons of the arts to be mentioned in the book in PDF that will speak of Ready Made Before 5 € each.


Acknowledgements

 

I sincerely thank all those who want to contribute to the initiative.

It is the first time that I undertake a crowdfunding initiative and I am really curious to see how it will work.  I am determined to complete the project anyway.


Object value

 

The Ready Made Before an object is produced in a limited edition of 500 pieces.
The Ready Made Before intended by Rebis is the reverse of the concept of Ready Made Duchamp.
What is the Ready Made? See the Ready made on Wikipedia

On this site: Ready Made Before - prototype you can see more details on the prototype.



Other Ways You Can Help


Do you like this project?  You can't contribute financially?

It can be of great help in promoting it even if you do speak with your friends or on Indiegogo and social media.

Ready Made Before

It's an Art Object

It 's a shopping bag

You decide

story:
Zawiyah

(zāwiyah ; زاوية ) - Arabic, literally; “corner, nook”

Zawiyah was born out of a need to provide young talented emerging Emirati artists a space or a “corner/nook” to create, meet, discuss, and exhibit their art.

With limited opportunities for recent art graduates, there was a need for another viable option for these artists, either directly working in Zawiyah studio spaces, exhibiting their work in the gallery, developing and offering creative workshops, establishing internship opportunities, and working on collaborative projects with local community organizations and educational institutions. 

We need your financial help to see this unique and innovative arts project realized.

What We Need:

All monies raised will go directly to paying for the build-out costs of the studio spaces and gallery; 11 studios spaces, 1 gallery, arts library, artists wood/metal shop, community space for public arts related workshops/classes, and first year rental costs.  The studio rental will pay for the warehouse rental in the subsequent years.  If we don't reach our goal, the monies raised will go to paying the rent for the space and further funds will be sought to finish build out.  The Mina warehouse area is under new development and the goal is to hold on to the warehouse space as the demand of businesses seeking to move into this highly attractive growth area of Abu Dhabi. 

We are offering some unique perks and hopefully you will find them of value and contribute, but please remember, it is the act of supporting and giving to this project which is most important and we thank you in advance for supporting this unique project.

What this Project means to the Community:

This project will be a community arts 'center' creating a viable space for local emerging artists to work, exhibit, teach, explore, collaborate, and learn.  The community outreach will be invaluable for the city and outlying areas and hopefully contribute to the new arts scene within Abu Dhabi.  

Potential

With the anticipated opening of Saadiyat Island's Guggienhiem and Louvre museums, the Abu Dhabi Arts and Cultural scene is gaining international status.  These museums join the Manarat Al Saadiyat cultural district and further cement Abu Dhabi as the arts and cultural center of the Middle East.  Abu Dhabi will have international museums, however unlike Dubai, it still lacks smaller community based artist galleries and art venues.  Zawiyah Studio & Gallery will help to fill this void, and be a complementary component to the growing arts scene in Abu Dhabi City.

Russell Hamilton, Founder

Russell Hamilton holds an MFA in sculpture from the University of Washington, and a BA in Political Science from the University of Minnesota.

He has worked as a community artist in Minneapolis, East Harlem NYC, and Detroit. With professional exhibitions in Seattle, Atlanta, NYC, Detroit, Washington DC,  Minneapolis, and Japan.  He attended the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture and was a 12 month Artist-in-Resident at the Studio Museum In Harlem in NYC.  Currently he works as an Associate Professor in the College of Arts and Creative Enterprises at Zayed University, Abu Dhabi UAE.

He is founder and co-partner of Zawiyah Gallery & Studios.

Can't Contribute? That's OK

If you cannot help us, please share this campaign with your friends via any format and also use the Indiegogo share tool.  Thank you!
story_txt:
Zawiyah

(zāwiyah ; زاوية ) - Arabic, literally; “corner, nook”
Zawiyah was born out of a need to provide young talented emerging Emirati artists a space or a “corner/nook” to create, meet, discuss, and exhibit their art.

With limited opportunities for recent art graduates, there was a need for another viable option for these artists, either directly working in Zawiyah studio spaces, exhibiting their work in the gallery, developing and offering creative workshops, establishing internship opportunities, and working on collaborative projects with local community organizations and educational institutions.  
We need your financial help to see this unique and innovative 
arts project realized.
  What We Need: 
All monies raised will go directly to paying 
for the build-out costs of the studio spaces and gallery; 11 studios 
spaces, 1 gallery, arts library, artists wood/metal shop, community 
space for public arts related workshops/classes, and first year rental 
costs.  The studio rental will pay for the warehouse rental in the 
subsequent years.  If we don't reach our goal, the monies raised will go
 to paying the rent for the space and further funds will be sought to 
finish build out.  The Mina warehouse area is under new development and the 
goal is to hold on to the warehouse space as the demand of businesses seeking to move into this highly attractive 
growth area of Abu Dhabi.  
We are offering some unique perks and hopefully you will find them of value and contribute, but please remember, it is the act of supporting and giving to this project which is most important and we thank you in advance for supporting this unique project. 
What this Project means to the Community: 
This project will be a community arts 'center' creating a viable space for local emerging artists to work, exhibit, teach, explore, collaborate, and learn.  The community outreach will be invaluable for the city and outlying areas and hopefully contribute to the new arts scene within Abu Dhabi.   
Potential
With the anticipated opening of Saadiyat Island's Guggienhiem and Louvre museums,  the Abu Dhabi Arts and Cultural scene is gaining international status.  These museums join the Manarat Al Saadiyat cultural district and further cement Abu Dhabi as the arts and cultural center of the Middle East.  Abu Dhabi will have international museums, however unlike Dubai, it still lacks smaller community based artist galleries and art venues.  Zawiyah Studio & Gallery will help to fill this void, and be a complementary component to the growing arts scene in Abu Dhabi City. 
Russell Hamilton, Founder

Russell Hamilton holds an MFA in sculpture from the University of 
Washington, and a BA in Political Science from the 
University of Minnesota. 
He
 has worked as a community artist in Minneapolis, East Harlem 
NYC, and Detroit. With professional exhibitions in Seattle, Atlanta, 
NYC, Detroit, Washington DC,  Minneapolis, and Japan.  He attended the 
Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture and was a 12
 month Artist-in-Resident at the Studio Museum In Harlem in NYC.  
Currently he works as an Associate Professor in the College of Arts and 
Creative Enterprises at Zayed University, Abu Dhabi UAE.
He
 is founder and co-partner of Zawiyah Gallery & Studios.

via any format and also use the Indiegogo share tool.  Thank you!

story:
All products will be differentiated by racial theme.

The Four Races are:



In addition to our practical Limited Edition items like our Hats, EPIC Flags, Paper Plane Kits and Carpets we offer our more extravagant items in the four “vehicle classes” which follow the Trump 2016 + racial themes of the cards. The products with the price tags are for sale in substantial quantities. The vehicles are mostly for entertainment value but we'll make it happen if there's a willing customer. 


Trucker Hat - $30

Sombrero - $30

Rice Farmer Hat - $30

Veil - $30


VEHICLES

Again, the vehicles are mostly for entertainment value but we'll make it happen if there's a willing customer. 

The four "vehicle classes" are:


1. Motorcycle


2. Car


3. Airplane


4. Yacht


Yes, SERIOUSLY


Images of products below are examples, actual products may differ.



Nuf said

Motorcross the border

 

Tuk tuk

Arabian Horse





Built 'Murica Tough

 

*People Not Included

Buick Envision - Made in China

Camel


Trump Aerial Fleet

 Cessna

Stolen Military Designs - $101

Magic* Carpet - $1500


*Magic not included.



Weapons NOTINCLUDED

 


Includes GPS for night navigation Great for smuggling around the wall

Junk Ship

Kingdom 5KR - Google it

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_5KR

One more time, of the "Vehicles", the Paper Plane and the Magic Carpet are being mass produced, the rest of the vehicles are for entertainment, but we will get them to you if there is a willing buyer.

                             

*Magic not included. 

The Paper Plane and the Magic Carpet are being mass produced, the rest are for entertainment value, but we will get them to you if there is a willing buyer.


Follow along on our social media accounts to watch the other cards as they are revealed and for fantastic commentary on what we're sure will be a great ending to the Presidential Campaign Season.

Social Media:

Facebook Twitter Instagram Pinterest 


 

Availability:

All orders are pre-orders and may be subject to delays. The more extravagant products(Items over $10,000) may take longer.


Risks & Challenges:

Design - Back and forth with the artists may cause delays.

Sourcing - Manufacturers may take longer than they guarantee us.

Fulfillment - Shipping may take longer and given the anticipated scale we may have some hiccups along the way so please bear with us. 

Legal/Political - We have consulted with some of the top constitutional lawyers and are in the realm of parody and political free speech and think the world has bigger things to concern itself.


We are hard workers that will do our best to overcome these hurdles and other unforeseen issues that are sure to pop up along the way.

story:
Turn your scribbles into art masterpiece!

Hello everyone!

Have you ever thought that your scribble or photo can be a great work of art?

I always wanted to paint beautiful arts, but like many people I have not obtained masterpieces. But today, neural networks is ready to realize our dreams and our imagination into our life!

I began to develop an algorithm for combining the content of one image with the style of another image using convolutional neural networks.

 

                                    


I plan to use this algorithm to make a program that will be available to everyone. I will try to make the program so simple that people without any knowledge can use it.

Unfortunately I do not have enough funds to realize my ideas and thoughts into reality…

This algorithm requires powerful hardware, and I'm going to buy a powerful server on which the algorithm will be placed.

So the program can handle your "scribbles" in seconds and turn them into a masterpiece! Program will be able to handle high-resolution photos and outputs the result in an excellent quality!

Also you can use any pictures, photos and any original styles that you like to combine them.

Some psychedelic algorithm which will be in program:

One of others styles:



Software will be distributed FOR FREE and translated into many languages of the world! Thank you!

P.S.

If you like the idea, in the future I plan to open a mini-museum where you will find the best arts which were made using this program.

story:
Mi nombre es Julio Guerrero tengo 24 años y vivo en la ciudad de Iquitos. Hace tres años diseñé y presenté la primera colección del proyecto “Vistámonos de Iquitos”. Este proyecto busca crear conciencia sobre la necesidad de proteger, poner en valor y visibilizar el patrimonio arquitectónico de la ciudad y con él su historia, su gente, su identidad.

Vistámonos de Iquitos nació por la necesidad de tomar posición y protestar frente al maltrato que sufrió nuestro patrimonio arquitectónico, con la demolición de la sede de la Municipalidad de Maynas, uno de los edificios más emblemáticos de la ciudad en el año 2010; y de llamar la atención de la población sobre la necesidad de identificarse con la ciudad, su historia y su patrimonio, a fin de protegerlos y visibilizarlos. 

En esta oportunidad les presento:

Este proyecto está basado en las formas, colores, textura e historias que acompañan a los azulejos que llegaron desde España y Portugal, durante la época del caucho.

Lo que hice fue tomar fotos de cada azulejo y vectorizar cada diseño para que pueda ser aplicado a la tela u otros materiales para el traje.

Uno de los costos del esplendor de Iquitos durante este periodo, fue el maltrato, la esclavitud y el genocidio que sufrieron muchas etnias amazónicas. Para esta muestra se ha seleccionado la iconografía de Boras y Huitotos, dos pueblos que casi fueron exterminados por los llamados barones del caucho; para crear un símbolo que represente a todos estos pueblos afectados por el  “progreso” y permita homenajearlos y reconocernos también como sus herederos.

La iconografía seleccionada sirvió para crear dos nuevos azulejos, los que servirán para reconocer, valorar y respetar el aporte de estos pueblos en la construcción física de la ciudad, su identidad y su historia.

                     Azulejo Huitoto                                             Azulejo Bora

A partir de cada uno de los 11 azulejos elegidos se realizó el diseño de un traje que será confeccionado respetando las formas colores y estilo de los mismos.  

Para la confección de cada traje se utilizarán diferentes técnicas y materiales, además se estamparán telas únicas para esta colección con el diseño de cada azulejo. Contamos con un gran equipo de artistas locales que hacen que este proyecto sea factible.

Lo recaudado en esta campaña servirá para cubrir el costo de los materiales y la exposición de esta colección en lugares públicos. 

Este proyecto ya está en marcha, pero necesitamos de tu apoyo para que se concluya en su totalidad. Tendremos recompensas desde postales únicas, hasta que tú nombre aparezca en la presentación oficial de esta colección.

Este segundo “Vistámonos de Iquitos” es una manera de hacer que la protesta se convierta en una fiesta en la que reconozcamos y valoremos lo que somos y lo que tenemos. Este concepto pretende llegar a muchas ciudades, así poder “Diseñar el mundo” que queremos.

La falta de un compromiso real de autoridades y de empresarios locales nos obliga a utilizar esta plataforma, contar con uds. y sumar su apoyo hasta conseguir la realización de este proyecto, en el que cada uno puede aportar y ayudar a su manera. Te invitamos a ser parte de esto y a invitar a tus amigos a conocer el proyecto.

Un cordial saludo

Julio Guerrero

story:
A collaborative project by sex workers and artists shifting the focus of the 'object of desire' through archiving and art.



Although this is an ongoing project, we are kicking it all off with an exhibition that will take place on the 5th-13th August 2016 (Private view: 4th August) at the Red Gallery in Shoreditch, London, UK.

Exploring sex work through object biographies, Objects of Desire provides an alternative narration of being a sex worker to the binary of exploitation versus empowerment that often dominates popular discourse around sex work.

Through a focus on the personal stories of sex workers, from the everyday material dimensions of the work to relationships with clients, Objects of Desire purposefully shifts the conversation from one that focuses on the objectification of people to one about the kinds of social relations that are engendered by physical things. It examines how objects both reflect and shape the everyday relations sex workers have with their clients, lovers, families and others.

Through a series of workshops and events, the exhibition will invite discussion around the ways in which both sex and labor are perceived, understood and moralised in the UK today.

This exhibition comes at a time of vital need to broaden conversations about sex work away from abstractions and one dimensional stereotypes. As sex worker organizations worldwide continue fighting for decriminalization as the best model to secure their rights and better working conditions, they have been endorsed by human rights groups such as Amnesty International. However, debates around legislation often exclude sex workers voices. The 'Nordic Model' of criminalising clients, which was recently adopted in France, is being considered by a parliamentary inquiry in the UK, despite a growing body of evidence that it endangers sex workers and increases stigma.  

Amidst this context of political and legal contention, Objects of Desire takes the practice and everyday experience of sex work as a starting point for opening an alternative conversation on sex work. It is not merely an attempt to “humanize” sex workers through providing outsiders with a glimpse into their lives. Rather, sex workers’ stories about materiality and exchange challenge the wider public to reflect upon dynamics of gendered labor, complex hierarchies of power and care under capitalism, and the interplay of the emotional and material in all relationships.

Following an open call for objects from sex workers, Objects of Desire has collected gifts such as jam, The New Testament, an endoscopic camera, shiny leggings and a Blue Balls Fucking Machine (BBFM). Further to gifts, personal totems, such as a necklace, have been included. The necklace, which was bought for the first day of work, holds much significance to the owner despite their own description of it as ‘cheap and plastic’. The objects range from the erotic to the banal, however their biographies illuminate the ways in which the relations of sex work play out, are managed and sometimes surprise.


As Rori says about the Assorted M&S, Fortnum & Mason and Tesco jams and preserves she was given by a client…

“I’ve wondered why he always gives me preserves. I can see that he gets a lot of pleasure from giving me food and feeling that he is caring for me... But I’ve also noticed that he is very into bodily fluids and often says how nice it is that we “taste” each other. I wonder if the jars of sticky jam are a symbolic substance, a kind of proxy for bodily fluids... If me storing them in my cupboard and ingesting them is a way for him to transcend the boundaries of our sessions, inserting himself somehow into my home and body.”



Follow us on twitter for updates!
twitter.com/projectofdesire
See the Red Gallery listings!
 http://www.redgallerylondon.com/event/objects-desire


About us: 

Rori 

An anthropologist currently undertaking a Masters in social anthropology. Rori has an enduring interest in the stories and narratives of sex workers and has been an active sex worker in London for five years.

Mia 

An artist and curator generally interested in people and the politics of their relationships, experiences and histories. Currently researching and making work about fetish and sexual or intimate obsessions and fantasies.

Jeeva_d

Assistant curator, anthropologist and artist practitioner

Email contact for project: archive.ood@gmail.com


The fundraising

We are hoping to raise money which will aid us in starting up the archive, putting on a great exhibition, organising workshops for sex workers and allies and continuing the project further. To break it down, we have written a list of some of the tasks involved in each step which will cost us:
Starting the archive
  • Postage for objects being sent from outside the UK
  • Making a website (hosting, domain, design and build)
The exhibition
  • Hire of venue
  • Printing of photographs
  • Printing of artworks
  • Getting objects and artworks in and out of the space (hiring a van)
  • Hanging photographs and artworks
  • Compensating artists, invigilators and helpers (with lunch if not a fee)
  • Decoration of the space (wallpaper or paint, fun glitzy stuff, furniture)
  • Private view (alcohol, DJs)
  • Second week party selling zines from workshops (as above)
The workshops
  • Paying speakers (for discussion workshops)
  • Providing materials (for art / craft workshops)
  • Printing zines / other artworks made in workshops
Continuing the project
  • Travelling to collect and photograph more objects
  • Taking the exhibition elsewhere
Luckily we have some great friends and contacts and have managed to get a lot of the things listed above (the designing and building of the website, for example) quoted at a much lower cost than anticipated. In the future, we aim to apply for funding for the project and it is often required to show that we have been running a functioning project and already have a portion of the money that we're asking for. We would like to be able to continue putting on exhibitions and pay artists and contributors in the future. Those of us who are running the project are not taking any profit from it or being compensated for our time (though we might buy ourselves lunch on installation and exhibition days as well as the helpers listed above!)
With the zines and artworks made in the workshops, we aim to sell these, with the profits returning to the people who made them. We are also hoping to sell some pre-existing things from sex workers and sex worker rights groups from a table in the exhibition all the time it's on.


Perks

Some of the perks we're offering are things which you'll be able to come and claim at the exhibition, or you can let us know if you can't make it there (or are not based in the UK) and we can post things out to you. Have a flick through our list of perks for everything from panties to photozines.


Other ways to contribute

If you can't contribute to the fundraiser but you want to help out and get involved then there are lots of ways that you can. 

If you are a sex worker (of any kind!) and you want to contribute a story, experience, object or artwork than you can email us on archive.ood@gmail.com and let us know. If you're not sure what to say about it, we have a set of questions that we've used to interview some people already. The way that your story or your object is shown in the archive is completely up to you and we will not make decisions on your behalf unless you chose to hand that responsibility to us. 
If you are not a sex worker and you want to help, you can also email us on the above email address too as we have lots of thing we would welcome help with. Please let us know: your background, your skills, where you found out about the project and why you are interested in it.
Come to our fundraiser! We are going to be throwing a fundraising party where we will be doing a pub quiz (more details to be updated here as soon as we know the location!) And please just spread the word for us! We are on Twitter as @projectofdesire and we would love if you could share our campaign on there and on Facebook and your other networks.

“I’ve wondered why he always gives me preserves. I can see that he gets a lot of pleasure from giving me food and feeling that he is caring for me... But I’ve also noticed that he is very into bodily fluids and often says how nice it is that we “taste” each other. I wonder if the jars of sticky jam are a symbolic substance, a kind of proxy for bodily fluids... If me storing them in my cupboard and ingesting them is a way for him to transcend the boundaries of our sessions, inserting himself somehow into my home and body.”




Follow us on twitter for updates!twitter.com/projectofdesire
See the Red Gallery listings! http://www.redgallerylondon.com/event/objects-desire

About us: 
Rori 


An anthropologist currently undertaking a Masters in social anthropology. Rori has an enduring interest in the stories and narratives of sex workers and has been an active sex worker in London for five years.
Mia 


An artist and curator generally interested in people and the politics of their relationships, experiences and histories. Currently researching and making work about fetish and sexual or intimate obsessions and fantasies.
Jeeva_d
Assistant curator, anthropologist and artist practitioner

Email contact for project: archive.ood@gmail.com

The fundraising
We are hoping to raise money which will aid us in starting up the archive, putting on a great exhibition, organising workshops for sex workers and allies and continuing the project further. To break it down, we have written a list of some of the tasks involved in each step which will cost us:
Starting the archive


Postage for objects being sent from outside the UK

Making a website (hosting, domain, design and build)

The exhibition


Hire of venue


Printing of photographs

Printing of artworks
Getting objects and artworks in and out of the space (hiring a van)
Hanging photographs and artworks
Compensating artists, invigilators and helpers (with lunch if not a fee)
Decoration of the space (wallpaper or paint, fun glitzy stuff, furniture)
Private view (alcohol, DJs)
Second week party selling zines from workshops (as above)

The workshops

Paying speakers (for discussion workshops)
Providing materials (for art / craft workshops)
Printing zines / other artworks made in workshops

Continuing the project

Travelling to collect and photograph more objects
Taking the exhibition elsewhere

Luckily we have some great friends and contacts and have managed to get a lot of the things listed above (the designing and building of the website, for example) quoted at a much lower cost than anticipated. In the future, we aim to apply for funding for the project and it is often required to show that we have been running a functioning project and already have a portion of the money that we're asking for. We would like to be able to continue putting on exhibitions and pay artists and contributors in the future. Those of us who are running the project are not taking any profit from it or being compensated for our time (though we might buy ourselves lunch on installation and exhibition days as well as the helpers listed above!)
With the zines and artworks made in the workshops, we aim to sell these, with the profits returning to the people who made them. We are also hoping to sell some pre-existing things from sex workers and sex worker rights groups from a table in the exhibition all the time it's on.




Perks

Some of the perks we're offering are things which you'll be able to come and claim at the exhibition, or you can let us know if you can't make it there (or are not based in the UK) and we can post things out to you. Have a flick through our list of perks for everything from panties to photozines.

Other ways to contribute
If you can't contribute to the fundraiser but you want to help out and get involved then there are lots of ways that you can. 
If you are a sex worker (of any kind!) and you want to contribute a story, experience, object or artwork than you can email us on archive.ood@gmail.com and let us know. If you're not sure what to say about it, we have a set of questions that we've used to interview some people already. The way that your story or your object is shown in the archive is completely up to you and we will not make decisions on your behalf unless you chose to hand that responsibility to us. 
If you are not a sex worker and you want to help, you can also email us on the above email address too as we have lots of thing we would welcome help with. Please let us know: your background, your skills, where you found out about the project and why you are interested in it.Come to our fundraiser! We are going to be throwing a fundraising party where we will be doing a pub quiz (more details to be updated here as soon as we know the location!) And please just spread the word for us! We are on Twitter as @projectofdesire and we would love if you could share our campaign on there and on Facebook and your other networks.

story:
We’re undertaking some major renos to turn our space at 2625 Kaslo Street into every media artist’s dream facilities equipped with gear we know you’ll be drooling over! 

More than that, we’re giving our space a serious makeover to accommodate the needs of arts and community organizations that require a flexible venue to present their events in a professional yet accessible setting. 

It's time for more than a paint job

We love our new space, but it needs more than a coat of paint to meet the needs of media artists in the short and long term. Designer Scott Cohen has been working with VIVO to design a flexible space with improved and new facilities for the production, exhibition, education, and conservation of media art.

Meet the new VIVO. This is what we've got planned:

The good news is, we’ve secured the nuts and bolts funding and our Operation Yellow Helmet is in full gear. But we need your help to make sure that our dream plan for VIVO gets realized. 

We're going for a full on makeover!

Here’s what we can accomplish with your help:

  • PERMANENT!  Wheelchair access. (we’re going legit on this one, CoV get your stamp of approval ready!)
  • NEW!  Co-working space. A rare resource in the under-served communities of Grandview-Woodlands and Renfrew-Collingwood.

  • NEW!  Kitchen facilities. Finally, you can work or volunteer at VIVO and not have to eat doughnuts and McDonalds (unless you want to). Imagine the possibilities!
  • IMPROVED! Exhibition/Studio Space
    • Control Booth. Choose between a raised, discrete control booth  or accessible floor access.
    • New projectors (we know we don’t have to sell you on that one)
    • More projection surfaces (to make use of our new projectors of course!)
    • New staff entrance for concession area for quick kitchen access

And there's more!

  • MORE! Space for the Crista Dahl Media Library & Archive
    • Over 500 sq ft of newly-acquired climate-controlled, secured, video storage (‘cause after all, we do run the largest independent media arts archive in Western Canada!)

    • Private print archive with research and scanning area.

  • NEW!  Classroom/Workshop Space. 400+ sq ft dedicated classroom with a 4K flat panel screen.

  • MORE! Space for the Digitization Hub. The better to access all that rad vintage video gear we use to digitize your work.

  • NEW! Production Studio/Micro-Cinema.  For the first time at VIVO - a flex space that includes a 7.1 surround sound system; iPad Air 2; Mac Mini; Audio Interface; Projector and motorized screen.

If our plan doesn’t restore your faith in Vancouver having the potential to present some truly experimental and radical media work we don’t know what will!

If you're a MEDIA ARTIST:

  • new facilities and better technology
If you’re a cultural or COMMUNITY GROUP:
  • a quality, accessible, affordable venue

If you're a CONTEMPORARY ART LOVER:

  • Some of the most diverse programming in the city—from solo exhibitions to high-profile festivals—and access to 45 years of international media art.

If you're just INCREDIBLY GENEROUS:

  • Great perks AND knowing that you’ve supported local culture and our media artists.


Whose going to benefit from this new space?

EVERYONE!

Yes, our members, artists-in-residence, volunteers, exhibited artists, distributed artists, and artists represented in our archive will all be better served by our renovations. But VIVO serves many more people than that!

VIVO is a public venue. Our exhibition, educational and archive programs and services are open to everyone!  You just save more money on our classes if you become a member (sounds like a good idea, right?).

Small screenings and archive screenings are possible in the intimate setting of our Micro-Cinema. VIVO’s  Presentation/Production Studio will be available for short-term or large-scale production and accessible to members and community partners alike. And, of course, VIVO, individual artists, cultural and community groups will continue to host extraordinary public exhibitions in our Presentation space throughout the year.

Our Archive Collections remain accessible to everyone. Our expanded Digitization Hub allow us to more efficiently digitize your videos and continue to make our archival collection to you and international audiences.

Bottom line: it’s not about us, it’s about you - the media arts community and the community at large - benefiting from a one-of-a-kind, flexible, affordable and accessible venue. 

This will give you some idea of the numbers of people and types of organizations that benefit from a venue like VIVO -

We've worked with an amazing number of artists, presented a ton of public activities and welcomed a mob of media arts enthusiasts. Here's our yearly average for the last 5 years:


We're always up to partnering with new like-minded organizations and, over the years, we've had the opportunity to collaborate with amazing groups of people. In 2015 alone, we’ve partnered with the following organizations to co-present events in our space: 


We can't wait to see what you're going to create and present in our new space!


We know you love VIVO and VIVO loves you back! To thank you for your generous support our construction crew has crafted some special rewards. There's something to please everyone and every wallet, whether you're a music lover, yoga enthusiast, or old-timer with a collection of Umatic tapes collecting dust. Here's your chance to get your hands on some sweet tickets to Destroy Vancouver or Queer Arts Festival or a BlackFlash subscription; access  our workshops at a reduced price; double your investment in Video Bucks; purchase some serious art; attend exclusive events; put on your own event in our space, or become the proud owner of a custom-made Banana Theremin! 

Every contribution will get you a special "thank you" GO!GO! GIF(t)! All perks valued at $25 and up include an invite to our exclusive donor party, a voucher for you to enjoy a beverage on us next time you visit, and a VIVO tote bag!

It's hard to imagine anything more fun or inspiring than spending a few hours with the marvelous Margaret Dragu!  Margaret will guide the group through a Yoga class, frugal cooking class, Verb Frau wisdom, videos AND dinner with the artist. A truly original hands-on, hands-in-the-air, perk!

  SATURDAY JUNE 18 | 5PM @ VIVO

Margaret Dragu is a writer and artist who has worked in the genres of performance art, video and film, installation, and choreography. She was awarded the 2012  Governor-General’s Award for Visual Art and Media; is the recipient of City of Richmond’s Most Innovative Artist Award, Ethel Tibbett’s Woman of the Year Award for The Arts, Richmond Women’s Centre’s Inspirational Woman Award, & the Mall Peepre Award for Outstanding Fitness Leader. 


One of the great things about being an artist-run centre is having talented artists on our board. Three of them have generously offered their artworks as perks in our campaign. 

Gabriela Aceves Sepúlveda | Escribiendome

Size: 13" x 19"
Medium: Digital print on photographic paper
Date: 2011-2013

Artist Statement
Escribiendome explores the ways in which words and languages shape our sense of self and how, in turn, through our life experiences we blur, transgress and shape the meanings of the words that are used to define and categorize us. It consists of two video channels played in one split screen. In one video you see my hand writing words in English such as friend, artist, designer, student, Mexican, Canadian, migrant, landed immigrant, Latin, woman, minority, citizen, spouse, alien, mother, (…). In the other video you see my hand writing words in Spanish such as hija (daughter), sobrina (niece), nieta (granddaughter), prima (cousin), mujer (woman), comadre, amiga (friend), tapatía, (…). Through the repeated action of writing at some point in the video the words become illegible.

Gabriela Aceves Sepúlveda is an interdisciplinary media artist and cultural historian with a research focus on Latin American feminist media arts. Working at the intersections of video and performance, she uses video and multimedia installations to explore the social, political, and cultural structures that shape our sense of self.  She is assistant professor at the School of Interactive Arts and Technology at Simon Fraser University,  and a member of the Vancouver-based AKA collective.  

Matilda Aslizadeh | Deities (VIVO Edition)

Size: 10”X 10”
Medium: Lightjet print
Date: 2016

Artist Statement
Deities is one of a  series of photographic and video works that explore the destruction and creation of artifacts in light of nostalgia, iconoclasm and notions of cultural authenticity.

Matilda Aslizadeh is a visual artist who works in a hybrid style between video, photography and animation and has a persisting interest in (re) thinking narrative structures.  Her work has been exhibited internationally in galleries and film festivals, most recently at Art Souterrain (Montreal) and the Kitchener-Waterloo Art Gallery (Kitchener).  Matilda teaches courses in photography, video production, critical theory and digital media at Emily Carr University of Art and Design and Kwantlen Polytechnic University.

Mariane Bourcheix-Laporte | I Would Like To Revolutionize But I Am Stuck With Reform

 Size: 12”X 12” diptych (unframed)                                                                                                   Medium: Gouache on paper                                                                                                      Date: 2014/2016

Artist Statement
I Would Like to Revolutionize But I Am Stuck With Reform  is part of the ongoing series of print, performance and installation-based works that examines the tensions existing between one’s revolutionary dreams and the realities of the politico-institutional instruments governing social life. The work appropriates a quote from Lucy Lippard and its form plays with the of performativity of activist referents.   

Mariane Bourcheix-Laporte is an interdisciplinary artist and independent curator based in Vancouver. She completed an MFA in Interdisciplinary Studies at Simon Fraser University. Her artistic and curatorial projects have been shown throughout Canada and, more recently, internationally. Recent exhibitions and performances include: Coalesce Performance Festival (Ottawa, 2015); Through a Window, Audain Gallery (Vancouver, 2015); Deformes Performance Biennale (Valdivia, Chile, 2014); Intersite Festival (Calgary, 2014); Langague/Language (Arprim, Montréal, 2014). Recent curatorial projects include: Acts of Spatial Decolonization, Decoy and Balcone (Vancouver, 2015); Glissements de terrains, Capture Photography Festival (Vancouver, 2015); and Collective Walks/Spaces of Contestation, UNIT/PITT (Vancouver 2013-14). She has contributed articles to Inter: art actuel, Decoy, Esse: art & opinions and C Magazine and recently published the artists’ book Tracts through Publication Studio Vancouver.

We asked Sean Michaels -  thereminist, "Said the Gramophone" founder, and winner of the Giller Prize for his fictional novel about Leon Theremin - "Us Conductors" -  to conceptualize a theremin for us.  The result is a surreal instrument crafted by Vancouver artist Jaeden Chayce Leimert, working in concert with Michaels to realize his concept.  
Material: Laminated plywood
Theremin: PAIA Theremax Model 9505
Length: wooden case - 66cm; case including loop antennae - 82cm
Height: at center of case - 16.5cm

  


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

Risks and Challenges

At the time of this campaign’s launch we have  85% of our funding confirmed.  We gratefully acknowledge the financial support of the City of Vancouver, Heritage Canada, the Canada Council, SVES’ Inner Circle members, Frans Van De Ven,  and all the other individual donors to our infrastructure project.  

We have created a budget-conscious yet impactful plan for this renovation. As outlined, it will radically transform our space adding greater accessibility and flexibility in use for VIVO, our members and the community.

As with all large infrastructure projects, however, there is always the possibility of unavoidable delays and cost overruns. For this reason we cannot guarantee that the entire project will be completed before the end of 2016. The exact results will is dependent to some degree on the success of securing the final 15% of funding, including the amount represented by this crowdfunding campaign.  

All perks are secured and guaranteed. Perks available May 15th. Details will be emailed to you. 

Who We Are

VIVO Media Arts Centre is one of Canada’s leading artist-run centres dedicated to the exploration, creation, and dissemination of media arts. VIVO is dedicated to creating a vibrant community of media artists through innovative programs and opportunities, and inspiring artistic development by being a space for incubation and creative exchange. We value risk-taking and radical paradigms and encourage, facilitate and inspire artists to take on challenges beyond those taken up through established art forms. We distinguish ourselves by bridging the gap between the hacker, DIY, and maker communities and experimental practice and critical art theory. We engage the broader community in dialogue, new art experiences, and hands-on learning.

VIVO directly supports artists and independent community-based producers to develop, exchange, and disseminate their skills in a supportive environment through accessible services and programs.  We achieve our mandate by providing:

·  The material necessities for quality production at affordable rates: production equipment, media post-production facilities, studio and exhibition space.

·  A broad range of skills development and education opportunities that allow for the exploration of, and experimentation with, technology within a critical, artistic framework.

·  The extensive resources of our Archive, rigorous research opportunities, dissemination and creative projects.

·  Support of the aspirations and livelihood of artists through our international distribution services (Video Out), work exchange program, employment in our contemporary exhibition program as artists, curators, lecturers, writers, and technicians, and, as staff at VIVO.

Facilities

Our leased facility at 1965 Main Street in Vancouver was sold in 2013. In August 2014, VIVO relocated to 2625 Kaslo Street in the Collingwood-Renfrew area and holds a 10 year lease with the City of Vancouver.

artist-run centres dedicated to the exploration, creation, and dissemination of
media arts. VIVO is
dedicated to creating a vibrant community of media artists through innovative
programs and opportunities, and inspiring artistic development by being a space
for incubation and creative exchange. We value risk-taking and radical
paradigms and encourage, facilitate and inspire artists to take on challenges
beyond those taken up through established art forms. We distinguish
ourselves by bridging the gap between the hacker, DIY, and maker communities
and experimental practice and critical art theory. We engage the broader community in dialogue, new art
experiences, and hands-on learning.
VIVO directly supports
artists and independent community-based producers to develop, exchange, and
disseminate their skills in a supportive environment through accessible
services and programs.  We achieve our
mandate by providing:
· 
The material
necessities for quality production at affordable rates: production equipment,
media post-production facilities, studio and exhibition space. 
· 
A broad range of skills
development and education opportunities that allow for the exploration of, and
experimentation with, technology within a critical, artistic framework. 
· 
The extensive resources of our Archive, rigorous research
opportunities, dissemination and creative projects. 
· 
Support of the
aspirations and livelihood of artists through our international distribution
services (Video Out), work exchange program, employment in our contemporary
exhibition program as artists, curators, lecturers, writers, and technicians,
and, as staff at VIVO.
Facilities
Our leased facility at 1965 Main Street in Vancouver was sold in 2013. In August 2014, VIVO relocated to 2625 Kaslo Street in the Collingwood-Renfrew area and holds a 10 year lease with the City of Vancouver.

story:
"We Made It" is a celebration of the work created by a select group of The Arts University Bournemouth's Illustration class of 2016. Come see the best of the best, exhibiting in an exciting and innovative group show to round off our three years of studying!


From the 8th to the 10th of July, with the private view on the evening of the 7th, we will be in London, exhibiting in the 71A Gallery, Shoreditch.

The money raised through this page will go towards paying for numerous aspects of our exhibition, including marketing and venue hire. So far, we have put lots of hard work into fundraising for our graduate show; by putting on markets and some cheeky nights on the town. This has put us on the right track towards our fundraising targets, however, we are looking to you for your support! 


This exhibition could really kickstart our careers within the competitive illustration industry. We need you to dig deep and donate whatever you can to our humble cause. Please be generous and help us achieve our fundraising goal so we can present a cracking graduate show!


Take a look at our website for more information about the show, and to see more examples of the incredible work that will be exhibited in July. If you're into the whole social media thing, check out our Facebook and Instagram for all the exciting updates.


If you're anything like us students (a bit skint), just remember sharing this page will really help us out; feel free to share this page, our website and social media sites.


Thank you in advance & if you find yourself in London from the 8th to the 10th of July, pop in and visit; we'd love to see you!

Many thanks,

Arts University Bournemouth Graduates of 2016

story:
I'm making a dance y'all.  It's going to be fun.  It's an evening length trio called, "Us Kids Are Alone in the House" that will premiere at The Salvage Vanguard Theater in Austin, TX on March 3rd, 2016.  I'm choreographing, producing, and doing the set and costume design (which will feature elements of my soft sculpture).  The structure of the work and the choreography begin with memories of being a kid alone at home.  The dance will move through three distinct sections: it starts with the youthful perception that the authority of the world is inscrutable,  moves to the childhood (and adult) tumult of being let loose into one's own authority in a space that is structured by the authority of others, and arrives finally at the utterly adult realization that us kids really ARE alone in the house.  We are truly abandoned, un-moored, at our own mercy.  The dancers (Sara Paul, Alexa Capareda, Felicia McBride, and Kelsey Oliver) are forceful and special performers, and the evening will burst with inventive, funny, and compelling movement. 
     We need to round up an additional 3,500 dollars to make this project happen.  All funds will go directly towards basic project expenses: theater rental, rehearsal space rental, artist pay (dancers, sound and lighting designers), and promotion.  Each donation level includes an art gift and all donations over 50 dollars will receive fully mounted, ready-to-hang body parts.  If you've ever wanted to own a fabric body part and you'd like to support this work, this is the time and place to do so!  Art gifts are listed below.  If you'd like a body part that you don't see here (including the x-rated ones) please contact me cause I can probably make it!  I'm just trying to keep this campaign family friendly.   If you'd like an art gift please make sure to select the one in your dollar range (or I'll assume you are foregoing the gift) and to provide your address.  If you are donating 50+ you may choose the poster and taxidermy portrait, one, or neither.  Thanks for your support! 
Magda

All contributions of 30$+ will receive a show poster on card stock.



All contributions of 50-99$ will receive a show poster and a 4x6ish taxidermy portrait of a nose (fabrics and wood mount vary).


All contributions of 100-199$ will receive a show poster and an 8x10ish taxidermy portrait of a hand (fabrics and hand expression vary).


All contributions of 200-249$ will receive a show poster and an 8x10ish taxidermy portrait of a face (fabrics and expressions vary).


All contributions of 250$+will receive a show poster and a 10x14ish taxidermy portrait of the face of someone you love!  Send me a picture and I will render them in fabric.  All resemblances are utterly tenuous and un-guaranteed!

story:
Lavender Menace: A Hand Embroidery Project

When I was a child, my grandmother taught me to sew using dental floss and a few paper napkins. Over the past twenty-some years, I've refined my materials and technique. Now I'm an adult who has a lot of free time due to a spinal compression and resulting neuritis. As long as I have all this time on my hands, I want to use it to bring lovely things into other people's lives. Over the years I've made a number of things for friends who've encouraged me to take these skills to the rest of the world. No project is too small, large, silly, serious, simple, or complicated: just contact me. 

What This Project Needs & What You Get

Some day, perhaps long in the future, I'd love to let my handcrafts speak for themselves, and even earn enough money to support myself through them. However, I prefer to charge patrons only as much as is fair: for the supplies (needle, fabric, embroidery floss) and time needed to complete their ideas. Simpler designs, like slogans or basic cross-stitch, cost less; more elaborate ideas, like pieces of art or portraiture, will naturally cost a little more.

As much as possible, I prefer to work freehand instead of relying on patterns, so each patron can rest assured they're ordering something special. This also means I can work off photographs and with abstract ideas. If you need an embroidered velvet portrait of Black Jesus riding a neon unicorn, just ask.  

This fundraiser is meant as a platform on which to build my future work. I'm doing it now, instead of putting it off until an unknown date in future, in hopes that I'll get enough orders to do something nice for my mother's sixtieth birthday this spring (see more information below). 

Why?

If you choose to support this campaign by contracting me for a work of embroidery, you will receive something that was made by hand by a dedicated craftsperson and is unique by virtue of its concept as well as its workwomanship (see above).
You will also help me to do something special for a woman who's been through some things. My mom is a resilient lady who has been a proud lifelong member of the working class, struggles with some health issues of her own, and still shows up every day in her current job as an educator. She does great work, but has lost so much ground due to factors like "lack of health insurance" that she will probably never get to take significant time off or retire. 
She has never been to New Orleans and would love to go. I would love to give her something for doing all this life stuff and having successfully raised a human being too. Since she turns 60 in March 2016 and her workplace goes on a short spring break immediately thereafter, this feels like the perfect time!
Anything that happens beyond this goal, will just serve as a bonus and keep me working towards the future.

How Does It Work?

For each donation, I will produce a custom piece of hand embroidery. As noted above,  I base my rates on supplies (needle, fabric, embroidery floss) and time needed to complete an idea. Simpler designs, like slogans or basic cross-stitch, cost less; more elaborate ideas, like pieces of art or portraiture, will naturally cost a little more. 
After donating, I will email you to get a thorough idea of your concept -- you can have some photos ready to communicate your vision, but we can almost certainly talk it out if you can't find any.
During the creative process I'll send periodic updates to let you see how things are working out. That way, you can see progress and have a hand in shaping it yourself.

How Can I Help?

If you would like to help, but can't contribute, that's okay! Maybe you know someone who is trying to find the perfect special gift for someone, or wants just the right thing to put in just a certain spot in their home, and would like to purchase a work of embroidery for that exact purpose. If you don't mind linking to this campaign on social media, it would bridge the gap between that person and me.
If anyone would like to donate, but for some reason does not want a work of embroidery in return, that's also acceptable ...  although admittedly confusing. Please let me send you a postcard or something!

story:
Queen Things began as a painting series and exhibit envisioned by local emerging artist J’Nell Jordan to showcase images of powerful women. It has evolved into a desire to recognize local noteworthy women as Modern Day Queens.

This Campaign will raise money for a Three-day Event this Fall highlighting exceptional women in DC metropolitan area. Six women will be chosen from nominees for a commissioned painting celebrating their lives, what they do, and what they value.

Day 1: Awards ceremony with an unveiling of the paintings

Day 2: Art Exhibit & Pop Up Shop of Local Female Artists and Creatives

Day 3: Art-based Work Shop for Young Girls “Queens in Training”


The Impact

Queen Things was developed from a need for women to uplift, collaborate, learn from and inspire one another. In DC, Maryland, and Virginia, there are so many talented and exceptional female entrepreneurs, creatives, advocates, and philanthropists. The goal of this project is to, not only highlight these remarkable women but to call us together to work with one another and plant the seeds that will foster that same spirit in the generations of ambitions girls to come.

   

         


Queen Things is a mindset to remind yourself daily, not necessarily that you are "royalty," but that you should uphold yourself to those standards. You should lift your head up high every day as to not drop your "invisible crown" and be the best example of a human being as you can be to those in your reach. We are here not to merely exist, but to live purposely. Personally, I am most inspired when I see other woman taking on challenges, problem solving and advocating for those who may not be able to do so on their own. It makes me want to do more. This past year, I've been brainstorming ways in which I can make my art bigger than myself and reach those around me. Life is too short not to connect and lift up one another.I want to bring us together so we can and give 6 exceptional women their flowers while they're still here. The only way I know to do that is through the gift of art. I've been successfully painting portraits and commissioned work for 6 years, and I'm very excited to do this for the selected and deserving woman chosen from the nominations. I am taking nominations starting now at www.jnelljordan.com/queenthings as well as getting together local female entrepreneurs and organizations to make this three day event a success.

   

The Goal is $15,000

The Venue/Decor Costs for 3 days, a bartender and Caterer for Award Ceremony &  Pop up Shop.  Snacks and Drinks for Workshop. Marketing Costs: Postcards, SIgnage, Advertising, Entertainment for Unveiling/Award Ceremony. (Dancers, Poet, Video Presentation). Awards for Recipients and Small Gifts for Participating Female Entrepreneurs/Creatives, Supplies for painting Six 3 ft x 3 ft Commissioned Paintings, Videographer/Photographer Fees, Registration Fees and Materials for "Queens In Training" Workshop,  and Speaker Fees for workshop.

We Value your Contribution!

Anywhere from $5 to $1,000 with the following "Perks"
$5 - A digital and printable download of the Queen Things Calendar 


$10 - 2 Queen Things Magnets 


$25 - Do It For the Girls PART 1 - 1 of 2 Limited Edition Fine Art Prints 8"  to 11"

  


$40 - Queen Things (physical) Professional Printed 2016 calendar


$50  - Queen Crown Wear (Logo Cap) + 1 of 2 Limited Edition Prints Above


$75 - "Sleep Like a Queen" Fine Art Printed Pillow + 1 of 2 Limited Edition Prints Above


$90  - #MiniQUEEN : I Paint the "Queen" in you.  I paint a mini original (6 x 6") of you, or the woman of your choice. You send me a picture, I do the portrait.  I'll even paint a little crown on the head, ya know, just as a reminder. ;)

 

  


$100 Ticket - Pre-Order your Unveiling/Awards Ceremony Ticket 

  


$125 - Entrepreneurial Ticket - Pre-Order your Unveiling/Awards Ceremony Ticket  with the option to to have your business/organization listed on the website/catalog of Female Entrepreneurs in the DC area.

$200 -  Pre-Order your Unveiling/Awards Ceremony Ticket and choose from the Queen Things Logo Cap or Pillow above

$275 - Do It For the Girls PART 2 - 1 of 2 Limited Edition Fine Art Canvas Reproduction  18"  to 24" (reproductions come ready to hang stretched on canvas)

  
$300 - Live Painting at your Next Event OR a Custom Portrait/Painting of up to 2 people (Up to dimensions of 18 x 24")


SPONSORSHIP PACKAGES from $250 - $2,500:  Pre-Order your Unveiling/Awards Ceremony Ticket(s) and have your business/organization listed on the website/catalog  as one of the Female Entrepreneurs in the DC area  WITH Ad Space in the catalog and your product/services marketing added to the "goody bags". This will also cover a table/booth space for your organization at the Pop up Shop/Art Exhibit on Day 2. 
Bronze Entrepreneurial - $250
Silver Entrepreneurial - $500
Golden Business - $1,000
Platinum Business $2,500

Risks & Challenges
 As for the planning for an event at this scale I will need help, I have a core team of women who have years of experience in event planning, educational workshops/programs, budget management and publicity/advertising. I may not make my goal, and that's okay. This will still happen. We are canvassing for business and non-profits. Even if we have to scale back, it will be a beautiful...maybe 2 -day event? :)

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can't contribute $$$, doesn't mean you can't help! 

Want to participate? We're currently looking for women either interested forming 3 small committees (in education, event planning and public relations) or women interested in participating in a juried art exhibit/pop up shop to make this 3-day event a success! Email me at jnelljordan@gmail.com, or fill out the participation form on my website at www.jnelljordan.com/queenthings

Nominations! Know an exceptional woman in Washington, DC, Maryland or Virginia? I'm sure you do... I am taking nominations starting now at www.jnelljordan.com/queenthings. We're looking for remarkable woman making moves in entrepreneurship, philanthropy, advocacy/community, and of course, the arts.

Spread the word! You can get the word out and make some noise about this project campaign.  You can use the Indiegogo share tools and tag the campaign with #QueenThingsART below!
